action.action-desc: Mr. Hunter (for himself, Mr. Hollingsworth, Mr. Jones, Mr. Grothman, and Mr. Sensenbrenner) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

form.official-title: To direct the Secretary of Transportation to issue regulations relating to commercial motor vehicle drivers under the age of 21, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Developing Responsible Individuals for a Vibrant Economy Act or the DRIVE-Safe Act.

section.header: Apprenticeship program for commercial drivers under the age of 21

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, the term apprentice means an individual under the age of 21 who holds a commercial driver’s license.

paragraph.text: may drive a commercial motor vehicle in interstate commerce while taking part in the 120-hour probationary period (as described in subsection (c)(1)) and the 280-hour probationary period (as described in subsection (c)(2)), pursuant to an apprenticeship program established by an employer that complies with the requirements of this section; and
may drive a commercial motor vehicle in interstate commerce once such apprentice completes such an apprenticeship program.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, the term apprenticeship program means one that is defined and structured as follows:

subparagraph.text: The apprentice shall complete 120 hours of on-duty time, of which at least 80 hours are driving time in a commercial motor vehicle.
In order to complete the 120-hour probationary period, an employer shall determine that the apprentice is competent in the following areas:

clause.text: Interstate, light city traffic, rural two-lane, and evening driving.
Logging and complying with rules concerning hours of service.

subparagraph.text: After completion of the requirements of paragraph (1), the apprentice shall complete 280 hours of on-duty time, of which at least 160 hours are driving time in a commercial motor vehicle.
In order to complete the 280-hour probationary period, an employer shall determine that the apprentice is competent in the following areas:

clause.text: Backing and maneuvering in close quarters.
Weighing loads, weight distribution, and sliding tandems.
Trip planning, truck routes, map reading, navigation, and permits.
Transporting hazardous materials, if properly endorsed.

paragraph.text: During the driving time described in paragraph (1), the apprentice may not operate a commercial motor vehicle on which hazardous materials placards are placed.
During the driving time described in paragraphs (1) and (2)—

subparagraph.text: the apprentice may only drive a commercial motor vehicle that has—

clause.text: governed speeds of 65 miles per hour at the pedal and 65 miles per hour under adaptive cruise control; and

subparagraph.text: the apprentice shall be accompanied in the cab of the commercial motor vehicle by an experienced driver.

paragraph.text: The employer shall maintain records, in a manner required by the Secretary of Transportation, concerning an apprentice’s satisfaction of the requirements of paragraphs (1)(B) and (2)(B).

If the apprentice is involved in a preventable, reportable to the Department of Transportation accident or pointed moving violation while driving a commercial motor vehicle as part of an apprenticeship program described in this section, the apprentice shall undergo remediation and additional training, until such apprentice can demonstrate to the employer’s satisfaction the performance benchmarks described in paragraphs (1)(B) and (2)(B).
The apprentice completes the apprenticeship program on the date such apprentice completes the probationary period described in paragraph (2).

subparagraph.text: Nothing in this Act shall preclude an employer from imposing additional requirements on an apprentice taking part in an apprenticeship program established pursuant to this section.
Nothing in this Act shall preclude an employer from requiring or installing additional technologies in a commercial motor vehicle in addition to the technologies described in paragraph (4)(A).

paragraph.text: The term commercial motor vehicle has the meaning given such term in section 390.5 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, as in effect on the date of enactment of this Act.
The term driving time has the meaning given such term in section 395.2 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, as in effect on the date of enactment of this Act.
The term experienced driver means an individual who—

subparagraph.text: is at least 21 years of age;
has held a commercial driver’s license for the 2 years preceding the date on which such individual serves as an experienced driver;

has had no preventable, reportable to the Department of Transportation accidents or pointed moving violations for the year preceding the date on which such individual serves as an experienced driver; and
has a minimum of 1 year of experience driving a commercial motor vehicle in interstate commerce.

paragraph.text: The term on-duty time has the meaning given such term in section 395.2 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, as in effect on the date of enactment of this Act.
The term pointed moving violation means a violation that results in points being added to the license of a driver, or a similar violation that the Secretary determines is comparable.

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall issue regulations that comply with the requirements of this Act.
